name: Preparation & Post-Op Care
pre_op_assessment:
1. Pre-operative Assessment & Optimization

  • History (AMPPLE): Allergies, Medications, Past history, Pregnancy/Last meal, Events. Assess functional reserve (METs - e.g., climbing 2 flights of stairs).
  • ASA Grading (Fitness):
    - I: Healthy.
    - II: Mild systemic disease (Smoker, Controlled HTN).
    - III: Severe systemic disease (COPD, Angina).
    - IV: Threat to life (Sepsis, Renal failure).
    - V: Moribund (Ruptured AAA).
  • Airway Assessment: Mallampati Score (I-IV) based on visualization of uvula/soft palate. Thyromental distance (<6.5cm = difficult).
  • Medication Management:
    - Stop: Warfarin (5 days, bridge with Heparin), Clopidogrel (7 days), ACE inhibitors (morning of surgery to prevent hypotension), Oral Hypoglycemics (morning of), COCP (4 weeks before major surgery for VTE risk).
    - Continue: Beta-blockers, Statins, Antiepileptics, Thyroxine, Steroids (Consider IV hydrocortisone 'stress dose' if HPA axis suppressed).
pre_op_investigations:
2. Targeted Investigations

  • Full Blood Count (FBC): Baseline Hb (transfusion trigger), WBC (infection), Platelets (epidural safety).
  • Urea & Electrolytes (U&E): K+ (arrhythmia risk if high/low), Creatinine (drug dosing/contrast risk), Na+.
  • Coagulation Screen (PT/APTT): Only if history of bleeding, liver disease, or anticoagulants.
  • Group & Save (G&S): Standard. Crossmatch only if significant blood loss is anticipated.
  • ECG: Males >40, Females >50, or any cardiac history. Look for ischemia, arrhythmia, conduction blocks.
  • Chest X-ray (CXR): Not routine. Indicated for active respiratory symptoms or suspected metastasis.
  • Cardiopulmonary Exercise Testing (CPET): For high-risk major surgery to objectively measure Anaerobic Threshold (AT).
pre_op_prep:
3. Patient Preparation Protocols

  • Informed Consent: Must explain diagnosis, procedure, specific risks (e.g., stoma, nerve injury), benefits, and alternatives. Patient must have capacity.
  • Fasting Guidelines (2-4-6 Rule):
    - 2 Hours: Clear fluids (water/tea).
    - 4 Hours: Breast milk.
    - 6 Hours: Solids/Formula/Cow's milk.
    Rationale: Minimizes gastric volume/acidity to prevent Mendelson's Syndrome (aspiration pneumonitis).
  • VTE Prophylaxis: Assess risk (e.g., Caprini Score).
    - Mechanical: TED stockings, Intermittent Pneumatic Compression (IPC).
    - Chemical: LMWH (Enoxaparin) usually 6-12h pre-op and daily post-op.
  • Antibiotic Prophylaxis: Single dose at induction (within 60 mins of incision). Indicated for Clean-Contaminated (opened viscus) or Implant surgery.
  • Bowel Prep: No longer routine (ERAS). Only for specific cases (e.g., rectal cancer requiring defunctioning loop ileostomy construction).
post_op_immediate:
4. Immediate Post-Op (Recovery/PACU)

A (Airway): Patency, Gurgling (secretions), Snoring (obstruction).
B (Breathing): RR (12-20), SpO2 (>94%). Check for atelectasis/depression.
C (Circulation): HR, BP, Capillary Refill. Check Urine Output (>0.5ml/kg/hr). Check drains/wound for Primary Hemorrhage.
D (Disability): GCS, Pupil size, Pain score.
E (Exposure): Temperature (Active warming to prevent coagulopathy).
Documentation: Operation note, post-op orders (IV fluids, analgesia, antibiotics, DVT prophylaxis).
post_op_ward:
5. Ward Management & Complications

  • Analgesia (WHO Ladder):
    1. Non-opioid (Paracetamol/NSAIDs).
    2. Weak Opioid (Codeine/Tramadol).
    3. Strong Opioid (Morphine/PCA). Monitor for respiratory depression.
  • Fluid Balance: Daily maintenance (25-30ml/kg H2O, 1mmol/kg Na/K) + Replacement of losses (NGT, Stoma, Drains, Vomit).
  • Enhanced Recovery (ERAS): Early mobilization (prevents DVT/Ileus), Early enteral feeding (prevents gut atrophy), Removal of catheters/drains ASAP.
  • Complications Timeline (The 5 W's):
    - Day 1-2 (Wind): Atelectasis (collapsed alveoli). Most common fever cause. Rx: Physio.
    - Day 3-5 (Water): UTI (Catheter). Rx: Remove and treat.
    - Day 5-7 (Wound): SSI (Surgical Site Infection). Redness, pain, pus. Rx: Open sutures, drain pus. Anastomotic Leak (Tachycardia, Pain, CRP spike).
    - Day 7+ (Walk): DVT/PE. Rx: Therapeutic anticoagulation.
    - Anytime (Wonder Drugs): Drug fever, Transfusion reaction, Cannula site phlebitis.

name: Routine Biochemical Tests
hematology:
Full Blood Count (FBC)

  • Hemoglobin (Hb):
    - Microcytic (<80fL): Iron deficiency (Chronic GI bleed/cancer) or Thalassemia.
    - Normocytic (80-100fL): Acute blood loss, Anemia of Chronic Disease (Renal failure/Malignancy).
    - Macrocytic (>100fL): B12/Folate deficiency, Alcohol abuse, Hypothyroidism.
  • White Cell Count (WBC):
    - Neutrophilia: Bacterial infection, Tissue necrosis (Pancreatitis/MI), Trauma/Surgery (Sterile inflammation).
    - Lymphocytosis: Viral infection, Chronic infection (TB), Lymphoma/CLL.
    - Leukopenia: Severe Sepsis (bone marrow suppression), Chemotherapy, Hypersplenism.
  • Platelets:
    - Thrombocytopenia (<150): Sepsis, DIC (consumption), Massive Transfusion (dilution), Liver disease. Spontaneous bleeding risk if <20.
    - Thrombocytosis: Reactive (Infection/Bleed/Splenectomy), Malignancy.
biochemistry:
Urea & Electrolytes (U&E)

  • Sodium (Na+):
    - Hyponatremia: Common post-op (SIADH due to stress, Fluid overload with 5% Dextrose).
    - Hypernatremia: Dehydration (free water loss), Diabetes Insipidus.
  • Potassium (K+):
    - Hyperkalemia (>5.5): EMERGENCY. Causes: Renal failure, Acidosis (H+/K+ shift), Rhabdomyolysis, Suxamethonium. Effects: Peaked T waves -> VFib/Asystole. Rx: Calcium Gluconate (Cardioprotection) + Insulin/Dextrose.
    - Hypokalemia (<3.5): Causes: Vomiting, Diarrhea, Diuretics. Effects: Paralytic Ileus, Muscle weakness.
  • Urea & Creatinine:
    - Creatinine: Muscle breakdown product. Specific for intrinsic renal function.
    - Urea: Protein metabolite. Isolated Rise: Suggests Upper GI Bleed (digested blood protein absorption) or Dehydration (Pre-renal).
liver_profile:
Liver Function Tests (LFTs)

  • Bilirubin:
    - Unconjugated: Pre-hepatic (Hemolysis, Gilbert's).
    - Conjugated: Post-hepatic (Biliary Obstruction - dark urine/pale stool).
  • Enzymes:
    - ALT/AST: Hepatocellular damage (Viral hepatitis, Ischemia, Drugs). ALT is liver-specific.
    - ALP: Cholestasis (Obstruction). Also raised in Bone disease (fracture/mets) and Pregnancy. Check GGT to confirm liver origin.
  • Synthetic Function:
    - Albumin: Long half-life (~20 days). Low in Chronic Liver Disease, Malnutrition, Nephrotic syndrome, Sepsis (Capillary leak).
    - INR/PT: Short half-life (Hours). Best marker for Acute Liver Failure.
inflammatory_tumor:
Inflammatory Markers

  • CRP: Acute phase protein. Lags 12-24h behind clinical state. CRP >150 on Day 3-4 post-op predicts Complication/Leak.
  • Amylase: >3x Upper Limit = Acute Pancreatitis. Non-specific (raised in perforated ulcer, bowel ischemia). Short half-life (clearance).
  • Lipase: More specific and sensitive for Pancreatitis. Remains elevated longer.

Tumor Markers

  • CEA: Colorectal Ca (Monitoring).
  • CA 19-9: Pancreatic/Biliary Ca.
  • AFP: HCC / Testicular Ca.
  • PSA: Prostate Ca.
  • CA 125: Ovarian Ca.

name: Routine Imaging Studies
plain_xray:
Plain Radiography

  • Chest X-ray (Erect PA):
    - Pneumoperitoneum: Free air under diaphragm (crescent sign). Indicates perforated viscus (e.g., D1 Ulcer).
    - Pleural Effusion/Consolidation: Pneumonia, Pulmonary Edema.
  • Abdominal X-ray (Supine AXR):
    - Intestinal Obstruction: Dilated loops. Small Bowel (>3cm, central, Valvulae Conniventes crossing full width). Large Bowel (>6cm, peripheral, Haustra crossing partial width).
    - Toxic Megacolon: Transverse colon >6cm with loss of haustra.
    - Calcification: Renal stones (KUB), Chronic Pancreatitis, Gallstones (only 10% visible).
ultrasound:
Ultrasound (USG)

  • Mechanism: High-frequency sound waves. No radiation. Real-time.
  • Uses:
    - Hepatobiliary: Gold Standard for Gallstones (acoustic shadowing) and Biliary dilation.
    - Renal: Hydronephrosis, Bladder volume (residue).
    - Scrotum: Testicular Torsion vs Epididymo-orchitis.
    - Gynae: Ovarian cysts, Fibroids.
    - Vascular: DVT (compression US), Carotid stenosis.
    - Trauma: FAST Scan (Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma) for free fluid.
  • Pros/Cons: Safe in pregnancy/kids. Operator dependent. Cannot see through bowel gas or bone.
ct_scan:
Computed Tomography (CT)

  • Mechanism: Rotating X-ray beams. 3D reconstruction. High radiation dose (1 CT Abdomen = ~400 Chest X-rays = 3 years background radiation).
  • Contrast:
    - Intravenous (Iodine): Highlights blood vessels and organ perfusion. Phases: Arterial (Pancreas/Kidney), Portal Venous (Liver mets), Delayed/Excretory (Ureters).
    - Oral (Gastrografin/Water): Distinguishes bowel loops from abscesses/fluid.
  • Indications: Gold Standard for Acute Abdomen (Diverticulitis, Appendicitis in adults, Pancreatitis staging), Trauma (Pan-scan), Cancer Staging (TAP).
  • Risks: Contrast Induced Nephropathy (CIN - Check eGFR!), Anaphylaxis, Radiation (Cancer risk in young).
mri:
Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI)

  • Mechanism: Magnetic fields align protons. Radiofrequency pulses. No radiation.
  • Uses: Superior soft tissue contrast.
    - MRCP: Non-invasive view of biliary tree (stones/strictures).
    - Rectal Cancer: Staging (Mesorectal fascia involvement/Nodes).
    - Perianal Fistula: Mapping tracks (Parks classification).
    - Liver: Characterizing indeterminate lesions (Hemangioma vs Met).
  • Contraindications: Pacemakers, Cochlear implants, Metallic foreign bodies (eye), Severe Claustrophobia.
nuclear_medicine:
Nuclear Medicine

  • PET-CT: Uses 18-FDG (glucose analogue). Tumors/Infection are metabolically active and "light up". Used for staging occult metastases or recurrence.
  • HIDA Scan: Functional biliary scan. Failure of GB to fill = Cystic duct obstruction (Acute Cholecystitis).
  • Bone Scan: Detects osteoblastic metastases (Prostate/Breast).
  • V/Q Scan: Pulmonary Embolism (if CTPA contraindicated).

name: Endoscopic Procedures
upper_gi:
Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (OGDS)

  • Scope: Visualizes Esophagus, Stomach, Duodenum (to D2).
  • Diagnostic:
    - Biopsy: Gastric Ulcers (Rule out Ca), H. pylori (CLO test), Celiac Disease (Duodenal biopsy).
    - Surveillance: Barrett's Esophagus, Esophageal Varices.
  • Therapeutic:
    - Hemostasis: Variceal Band Ligation (EVL), Adrenaline/Heater Probe/Clips (Peptic Ulcer Bleed).
    - Strictures: Balloon dilation, Stenting (Esophageal Ca).
    - Feeding: PEG tube placement.
ercp:
ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography)

  • Scope: Side-viewing duodenoscope. Cannulates Ampulla of Vater. Uses Fluoroscopy (X-ray).
  • Indications: Therapeutic intervention for biliary/pancreatic disease.
    - Choledocholithiasis: Sphincterotomy (cut muscle) + Stone extraction (Basket/Balloon).
    - Obstructive Jaundice: Stenting (Plastic/Metal) for strictures or tumors (Ca Pancreas/Cholangio).
  • Complications: Pancreatitis (5-10%), Cholangitis (failed drainage), Hemorrhage, Perforation (retroperitoneal).
lower_gi:
Colonoscopy

  • Scope: Visualizes Rectum to Cecum (+ Terminal Ileum). Requires full bowel prep (laxatives).
  • Diagnostic: Gold Standard for Colorectal Cancer screening, IBD diagnosis/surveillance, Investigating Anemia/PR bleed.
  • Therapeutic: Polypectomy (Snare/Diathermy), Stenting (Obstruction), Decompression (Volvulus).
  • Risks: Perforation (1:1000 diagnostic, higher therapeutic), Bleeding (delayed up to 10 days post-polypectomy).

Flexible Sigmoidoscopy

  • Scope: Visualizes Rectum and Sigmoid (limited to 60cm). Quick prep (Enema only).
  • Uses: Screening for distal disease, assessment of hemorrhoids/fissures.
eus:
Endoscopic Ultrasound (EUS)

  • Scope: Ultrasound probe on tip of endoscope. Visualizes layers of gut wall and adjacent organs.
  • Uses:
    - Staging: T-stage (depth of invasion) for Esophageal/Gastric/Pancreatic/Rectal Ca.
    - Biopsy: FNA of mediastinal/celiac lymph nodes or pancreatic masses.
    - Biliary: Detects microlithiasis (stones) if MRCP equivocal.

name: Anatomy of the Stomach
structure:
Gross Anatomy & Relations

  • Parts:
    - Cardia: T11 level.
    - Fundus: Superior to gastroesophageal junction. Contains gas bubble.
    - Body: Main acid-secreting part. Contains Rugae.
    - Antrum: Grinding pump. G-cells (Gastrin).
    - Pylorus: Sphincter at L1 (Transpyloric plane).
  • Curvatures:
    - Lesser Curvature: Right border. Attached to Liver by Lesser Omentum (Hepatogastric lig).
    - Greater Curvature: Left border. Attached to Transverse Colon by Greater Omentum.
  • Bed of Stomach (Posterior): Pancreas, Spleen, Left Kidney/Adrenal, Transverse Mesocolon, Diaphragm. (Separated by Lesser Sac).
blood_supply:
Arterial Supply (Rich collateral network from Celiac Trunk)

  • Lesser Curvature:
    - Left Gastric Artery: Direct branch from Celiac Trunk (Largest).
    - Right Gastric Artery: Branch of Common Hepatic Artery.
  • Greater Curvature:
    - Left Gastroepiploic Artery: Branch of Splenic Artery.
    - Right Gastroepiploic Artery: Branch of Gastroduodenal Artery (GDA).
  • Fundus:
    - Short Gastric Arteries (5-7): From Splenic Artery via Gastrosplenic ligament. Surgical Danger: Can be avulsed during Splenectomy causing hemorrhage; or ischemia of fundus if splenic artery ligated proximally.
Venous Drainage: Parallel arteries. Left/Right Gastric -> Portal Vein directly. Short Gastric/Left Gastroepiploic -> Splenic Vein. Right Gastroepiploic -> SMV.
nerve_lymph:
Innervation & Lymphatics

  • Nerve Supply (Vagus CN X):
    - Anterior Trunk: From Left Vagus. Gives Hepatic branch.
    - Posterior Trunk: From Right Vagus. Gives Celiac branch.
    - Nerve of Latarjet: Branches supplying the Antrum (Pyloric pump) and Pylorus. Preserved in 'Highly Selective Vagotomy' to maintain emptying while denervating acid-secreting body.
  • Lymphatic Drainage: Complex, follows arteries.
    - Virchow's Node: Left Supraclavicular node. Enlarged in metastatic Gastric Ca (Troisier's sign) due to spread via Thoracic Duct.
    - Sister Mary Joseph Nodule: Umbilical metastasis via Falciform ligament.

name: Anatomy of Alimentary Tract
small_bowel:
Small Intestine (Duodenum, Jejunum, Ileum)

  • Duodenum: C-shaped, Retroperitoneal (except D1 cap). 4 parts. D2 contains Ampulla of Vater (Major Papilla) - entry of Bile/Pancreatic ducts.
  • Jejunum vs Ileum:
    FeatureJejunum (Proximal 2/5)Ileum (Distal 3/5)
    LocationLUQRLQ
    WallThick, Wide lumenThin, Narrow lumen
    Vasa RectaLongShort
    ArcadesFew (1-2)Many (3-5)
    FatLess (Windows visible)More (Mesentery encroach)
    LymphoidFewPeyer's Patches
large_bowel:
Large Intestine (Colon)

  • Distinguishing Features:
    1. Taeniae Coli: 3 longitudinal muscle bands. Converge at base of Appendix (guide for surgeons).
    2. Haustra: Sacculations caused by taeniae being shorter than bowel.
    3. Appendices Epiploicae: Fat tags.
  • Arterial Supply:
    - Midgut (SMA): Cecum, Appendix, Ascending, Proximal 2/3 Transverse. Branches: Ileocolic, Right Colic, Middle Colic.
    - Hindgut (IMA): Distal 1/3 Transverse, Descending, Sigmoid, Upper Rectum. Branches: Left Colic, Sigmoid, Superior Rectal.
    - Marginal Artery of Drummond: Anastomosis between Middle Colic (SMA) and Left Colic (IMA). Critical collateral.
  • Watershed Areas: Prone to Ischemic Colitis.
    - Griffith's Point: Splenic Flexure (SMA/IMA junction).
    - Sudeck's Point: Rectosigmoid junction (IMA/Iliac junction).
rectum_anal:
Rectum & Anal Canal

  • Rectum: 12-15cm. No taeniae/haustra/epiploicae.
    - Peritoneum: Upper 1/3 (Front/Sides), Middle 1/3 (Front only), Lower 1/3 (Sub-peritoneal).
    - Valves of Houston: 3 transverse folds.
  • Anal Canal: 4cm. Divided by Dentate (Pectinate) Line.
    Above Line: Endoderm. Columnar epithelium. Visceral sensation (Stretch/Dull - Painless Hemorrhoids). Portal drainage (Sup Rectal V). Lymph to Internal Iliac.
    Below Line: Ectoderm. Squamous epithelium. Somatic sensation (Pain/Temp - Painful Fissure/Hemorrhoids). Systemic drainage (Inf Rectal V). Lymph to Inguinal Nodes.
  • Sphincters:
    - Internal: Continuation of circular muscle. Involuntary (Autonomic). Resting tone.
    - External: Skeletal muscle. Voluntary (Pudendal Nerve). 3 parts (Subcutaneous, Superficial, Deep). Fuses with Puborectalis.

name: Anatomy of Hepatobiliary System
liver:
Liver Anatomy

  • Couinaud Segments (I-VIII): Functional units based on vascular inflow (Portal v/Hepatic a) and biliary outflow. Allows segmental resection.
    - Caudate Lobe (I): Independent. Drains directly to IVC. Spared in Budd-Chiari Syndrome.
    - Left Lobe: Segments II, III, IVa/b.
    - Right Lobe: Segments V, VI, VII, VIII.
  • Blood Supply (Dual):
    - Portal Vein (75%): Drains GI tract/Spleen. Rich in nutrients, low in O2.
    - Hepatic Artery (25%): Branch of Celiac. High in O2.
  • Ligaments:
    - Falciform: Attaches to ant. abdominal wall. Contains Ligamentum Teres (Obliterated Umbilical Vein).
    - Coronary/Triangular: Attach to diaphragm. Bare Area (no peritoneum).
biliary_tree:
Biliary Tract

  • Flow: Hepatocytes -> Canaliculi -> R/L Hepatic Ducts -> Common Hepatic Duct (CHD). CHD + Cystic Duct -> Common Bile Duct (CBD).
  • CBD Course:
    1. Supraduodenal: In free edge of Lesser Omentum (Hepatoduodenal ligament). Anterior to Portal Vein, Right of Hepatic Artery (Portal Triad).
    2. Retroduodenal: Behind D1 Duodenum.
    3. Infraduodenal/Intrapancreatic: Through/Behind Head of Pancreas.
    4. Ampulla: Joins Main Pancreatic Duct -> Ampulla of Vater -> Duodenum D2 (Sphincter of Oddi).
calots_triangle:
Calot's Triangle (Cystohepatic Triangle)

  • Boundaries:
    1. Superior: Inferior border of Liver.
    2. Medial: Common Hepatic Duct.
    3. Lateral: Cystic Duct.
  • Contents: Cystic Artery (usually from Right Hepatic), Lund's Node (Sentinel node).
  • Clinical Relevance: The 'Critical View of Safety' in Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy requires dissection of this triangle to conclusively identify the Cystic Duct and Artery before clipping, avoiding catastrophic CBD injury.
  • Moynihan's Hump: A tortuous Right Hepatic Artery ("caterpillar loop") that projects into the triangle. Can be mistaken for the cystic artery and ligated -> Right liver necrosis.

name: Anatomy of Genitourinary System
kidney:
Kidneys

  • Location: Retroperitoneal. T12-L3 vertebrae. Right is lower than Left (displaced by Liver).
  • Hilum Relations (Anterior to Posterior): Renal Vein, Renal Artery, Renal Pelvis (VAP).
  • Coverings (Inside out): Capsule -> Perirenal Fat -> Renal Fascia (Gerota's) -> Pararenal Fat.
  • Blood Supply: Renal Artery (Direct from Aorta L1/L2). Divides into 5 Segmental arteries (End arteries - infarction if blocked, no collateral). Left Renal Vein is longer (crosses aorta, receives gonadal vein).
ureter:
Ureters

  • Course: 25-30cm muscular tubes. Retroperitoneal.
    1. Run down anterior surface of Psoas Major (tips of transverse processes).
    2. Cross OVER the bifurcation of Common Iliac Arteries (Pelvic Brim/SI Joint).
    3. Run down lateral pelvic wall -> turn medially at Ischial Spine.
    4. Pass UNDER the Uterine Artery (females) or Vas Deferens (males) - "Water under the bridge". Risk of injury in hysterectomy.
    5. Enter bladder obliquely (prevent reflux).
  • Constrictions (Stone Sites):
    1. Pelvi-ureteric Junction (PUJ).
    2. Pelvic Brim (Crossing Iliacs).
    3. Vesico-ureteric Junction (VUJ - Narrowest point).
bladder_prostate:
Bladder & Prostate

  • Bladder: Extraperitoneal (when empty). Lined by Transitional Epithelium (Urothelium). Trigone: Smooth triangular area at base between ureteric orifices and internal urethra.
  • Prostate: Fibromuscular gland below bladder.
    - Peripheral Zone: Posterior. Site of 70% Cancers. Palpable on DRE.
    - Transition Zone: Surrounds urethra. Site of BPH (Hyperplasia).
    - Central Zone: Surrounds ejaculatory ducts.

name: Inguinal Canal Anatomy
structure:
Canal Boundaries (MALT Mnemonic)

A 4cm oblique tunnel above the inguinal ligament.
  • Muscle (Roof): Arching fibers of Internal Oblique & Transversus Abdominis (form Conjoint Tendon medially).
  • Aponeurosis (Anterior Wall): External Oblique Aponeurosis (throughout) + Internal Oblique (lateral 1/3).
  • Ligament (Floor): Inguinal Ligament (Poupart's) & Lacunar Ligament (Gimbernat's) medially.
  • Transversalis (Posterior Wall): Transversalis Fascia (throughout) + Conjoint Tendon (medial 1/3).
contents:
Contents

  • Males: Spermatic Cord. Contains:
    1. Vas Deferens.
    2. Arteries: Testicular, Cremasteric, Artery to Vas.
    3. Veins: Pampiniform Plexus.
    4. Nerves: Genital branch of Genitofemoral (cremasteric reflex), Sympathetics.
    5. Lymphatics.
  • Females: Round Ligament of Uterus.
  • Ilioinguinal Nerve: Runs through the canal (on top of cord), NOT inside the cord. Supplies sensation to inner thigh/scrotum. Risk of entrapment in repair.
hernia_relevance:
Clinical Anatomy

  • Deep Ring: Defect in Transversalis Fascia. Located at Mid-Inguinal Point (1.5cm above femoral pulse). Site of Indirect Hernia (enters canal -> scrotum).
  • Superficial Ring: Triangular defect in External Oblique Aponeurosis. Above Pubic Tubercle.
  • Hesselbach's Triangle: Area of weakness in posterior wall.
    - Medial: Rectus Abdominis.
    - Lateral: Inferior Epigastric Vessels.
    - Inferior: Inguinal Ligament.
    Site of Direct Hernia (bulges forward, rarely scrotal).

name: Femoral Triangle
boundaries:
Boundaries (SAIL)

  • Sartorius (Lateral).
  • Adductor Longus (Medial).
  • Inguinal Ligament (Superior).
  • Floor: Iliopsoas, Pectineus, Adductor Longus.
  • Roof: Fascia Lata, Cribriform fascia.
contents:
Contents (NAVEL - Lateral to Medial)

  1. Femoral Nerve (Outside the sheath!).
  2. Femoral Artery.
  3. Femoral Vein.
  4. Empty Space (Femoral Canal).
  5. Lymphatics (Cloquet's Node).
Femoral Sheath: Prolongation of abdominal fascia. Contains Artery, Vein, Canal. Femoral Nerve is lateral and outside. **Femoral Canal:** Site of Femoral Hernia.
Ring Boundaries: Inguinal Ligament (Ant), Pectineal Ligament (Post), Femoral Vein (Lat), Lacunar Ligament (Med - rigid/sharp -> Strangulation).
clinical_relevance:
Femoral Hernia

Protrusion of bowel/omentum into Femoral Canal. Present as lump Below and Lateral to Pubic Tubercle. High risk of strangulation (50%) due to tight neck. Urgent surgery indicated (McVay/Mesh plug).

name: Neck & Thyroid Anatomy
thyroid_relations:
Thyroid Gland Relations

Enclosed in Pretracheal Fascia (moves up with swallowing).
Anterior: Strap Muscles (Sternohyoid, Sternothyroid).
Posterior: Trachea (Medial), Carotid Sheath (Lateral), Parathyroids.
Nerves at Risk:
1. Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve (RLN): Ascends in tracheoesophageal groove. Supplies all intrinsic larynx muscles (except Cricothyroid). Injury -> Hoarseness (Unilateral) or Airway Obstruction (Bilateral).
2. External Laryngeal Nerve: Accompanies Sup. Thyroid Artery. Supplies Cricothyroid (tensors cords). Injury -> Loss of high pitch voice/fatigue.
vascular_supply:
Blood Supply

  • Arterial:
    - Superior Thyroid Artery: 1st branch of External Carotid Artery.
    - Inferior Thyroid Artery: Branch of Thyrocervical Trunk (Subclavian).
    - Thyroidea Ima (10%): Direct from Aortic Arch.
  • Venous:
    - Superior & Middle Thyroid Veins: Drain into Internal Jugular Vein.
    - Inferior Thyroid Veins: Drain into Brachiocephalic Veins.
triangles:
Surgical Triangles

Anterior Triangle: Midline, SCM, Mandible. Contains: Carotid Sheath, Thyroid, Larynx.
Posterior Triangle: SCM, Trapezius, Clavicle. Contains: Spinal Accessory Nerve (CN XI), Brachial Plexus, Subclavian vessels. *Danger:* CN XI is superficial and at risk during lymph node biopsy -> Trapezius palsy (shoulder droop).

name: Breast & Axilla Anatomy
structure:
Breast Structure

Modified sweat gland found in the superficial fascia.
Extent: 2nd to 6th Rib (Vertical), Sternal edge to Mid-axillary line (Horizontal).
Axillary Tail of Spence: Extension of breast tissue piercing deep fascia into the axilla.
Suspensory Ligaments of Cooper: Fibrous bands attaching skin to pectoral fascia. Invasion causes dimpling.
Retromammary Space: Loose areolar tissue allowing mobility over Pectoralis Major.
supply:
Vascular Supply

Arterial:
1. Internal Thoracic (Mammary): Branch of Subclavian. Supplies medial 60%.
2. Lateral Thoracic: Branch of Axillary (2nd part).
3. Thoracoacromial / Posterior Intercostals.
Venous: Matches arteries. Batson's Plexus: Valveless vertebral veins connect posterior intercostals to vertebral venous plexus. This is the pathway for metastasis to the Spine and Brain.
lymphatics:
Lymphatic Drainage

  • Axillary Nodes (75%): Main drainage pathway.
    Levels (Berg's Classification) defined by Pectoralis Minor:
    - Level I: Lateral/Inferior to Pec Minor.
    - Level II: Posterior to Pec Minor.
    - Level III: Medial/Superior to Pec Minor (Apical).
  • Internal Mammary Nodes (20-25%): Parasternal. Drains medial quadrants.
  • Sentinel Node: The first node draining the tumor. Identified via Blue Dye/Isotope mapping. Negative biopsy avoids full clearance.
nerves_at_risk:
Nerves at Risk (Axillary Clearance)

  1. Long Thoracic Nerve (C5-7): Runs on medial wall of axilla (on Serratus Anterior). Injury -> Winged Scapula.
  2. Thoracodorsal Nerve (C6-8): Runs with vascular pedicle to Latissimus Dorsi. Injury -> Weak shoulder extension/adduction ('handcuff motion').
  3. Intercostobrachial Nerve (T2): Sensory nerve traversing axilla to medial arm. Often sacrificed. Injury -> Numbness/Paresthesia of inner arm.

name: Regions of the Abdomen
regions_9:
The 9 Regions

Divided by Mid-clavicular lines (vertical), Transpyloric plane (L1), and Transtubercular plane (L5).
  • Right Hypochondrium: Liver (Right lobe), Gallbladder, Hepatic flexure, Right Kidney/Adrenal.
  • Epigastrium: Stomach, Liver (Left lobe), Pancreas (Body/Tail), Duodenum (D1-D4), Transverse Colon, Aorta.
  • Left Hypochondrium: Spleen, Stomach (Fundus), Splenic flexure, Pancreas (Tail), Left Kidney.
  • Right Lumbar (Flank): Ascending Colon, Right Kidney, Small Intestine.
  • Umbilical: Small Intestine (Jejunum/Ileum), Transverse Colon, Aorta/IVC, Omentum.
  • Left Lumbar (Flank): Descending Colon, Left Kidney, Small Intestine.
  • Right Iliac Fossa (RIF): Cecum, Appendix, Terminal Ileum, Right Ovary/Tube.
  • Hypogastrium (Suprapubic): Bladder (if full), Uterus, Sigmoid Colon, Small Intestine.
  • Left Iliac Fossa (LIF): Sigmoid Colon, Left Ovary/Tube.
planes:
Key Landmarks

Transpyloric Plane (L1): Cuts through tips of 9th costal cartilages. Contains: Pylorus, Pancreas neck, SMA origin, Portal vein formation, Renal hila.
Mid-Inguinal Point: Halfway between ASIS and Pubic Symphysis (Femoral Artery).
McBurney's Point: 1/3 distance from ASIS to Umbilicus (Base of Appendix).

name: Shock
definition:
Definition & Pathophysiology

Acute circulatory failure leading to inadequate tissue perfusion and cellular hypoxia. Key Concept: Shock is defined by perfusion (Mental state, Urine output, Lactate, Capillary refill), NOT just blood pressure. Hypotension is a late sign.
classification:
Types of Shock

  • Hypovolemic: Loss of circulating volume. (Hemorrhage, Burns, DKA).
    Hemodynamics: Preload ↓, Cardiac Output (CO) ↓, SVR ↑ (Vasoconstriction - cold skin).
  • Cardiogenic: Pump failure. (MI, Arrhythmia, Valve rupture).
    Hemodynamics: Preload ↑ (JVP raised/Pulm Edema), CO ↓, SVR ↑.
  • Obstructive: Extracardiac physical blockage. (Tension Pneumothorax, Tamponade, Massive PE).
    Hemodynamics: Preload ↑, CO ↓, SVR ↑.
  • Distributive: Vasodilation / Relative Hypovolemia. (Sepsis, Anaphylaxis, Neurogenic).
    Hemodynamics: Preload ↓, CO ↑ (Hyperdynamic early), SVR ↓↓↓ (Vasodilation - warm skin).
management:
Management Priorities

1. Hypovolemic: Stop bleeding! Volume Resuscitation (Warmed Crystalloids -> Blood Products 1:1:1). Inotropes are contraindicated in an empty heart.
2. Cardiogenic: Fluid restriction. Inotropes (Dobutamine). Revascularization (PCI).
3. Septic: Sepsis 6 Bundle. Fluids first (30ml/kg). Vasopressors (Noradrenaline) if fluid refractory. Antibiotics <1hr.
hemorrhage_classes:
ATLS Classification of Hemorrhage (70kg male)

  • Class I (<15% / <750ml): Vitals normal. Slight anxiety. (Blood donation).
  • Class II (15-30% / 750-1500ml): Tachycardia (>100), Narrow Pulse Pressure (Diastolic rises), Tachypnea. Urine normal.
  • Class III (30-40% / 1500-2000ml): Hypotension (Late sign!), Tachycardia (>120), Confusion, Urine <15ml/hr. Requires Blood Transfusion.
  • Class IV (>40% / >2000ml): Coma, Anuric, Severe Hypotension/Undetectable. Immediate Exsanguination threat.

name: Metabolic Response to Injury
phases:
1. Ebb Phase (0-24h)

'Shock phase'. Goal: Immediate survival.
Features: Hypometabolism, Decreased Cardiac Output, Decreased Temp, Vasoconstriction. Insulin drops.
Priority: Resuscitation (Stop bleeding, restore volume).

2. Flow Phase (Days-Weeks)

'Catabolic phase'. Goal: Repair.
Features: Hypermetabolism (High CO, High Temp).
- Catabolism: Muscle protein breakdown (Gluconeogenesis) -> Negative nitrogen balance.
- Insulin Resistance: 'Stress Diabetes' (High blood sugar provides fuel).
- Fluid Retention: ADH (Water) and Aldosterone (Na+).

3. Recovery Phase

Anabolic. Restoration of fat/protein stores. Diuresis.

name: Wound Healing
process:
Phases of Healing

  • 1. Hemostasis (Mins): Vasoconstriction, Platelet plug, Fibrin clot formation (scaffold).
  • 2. Inflammation (Days 1-4): Neutrophils (kill bacteria) followed by Macrophages (The 'Conductor' - debride and secrete growth factors). Signs: Rubor, Calor, Tumor, Dolor.
  • 3. Proliferation (Days 4-21):
    - Fibroblasts: Lay down Collagen Type III (weak/disorganized).
    - Angiogenesis: Formation of new capillaries.
    - Granulation Tissue: Beefy red matrix.
    - Epithelialization: Migration of keratinocytes.
  • 4. Remodeling (3 weeks - 1 year): Collagen III replaced by strong Type I. Cross-linking. Scar contracts and fades. Max strength is 80% of original skin.
classification:
Types of Union

Primary Intention: Clean edges approximated by sutures. Minimal scar. Rapid.
Secondary Intention: Wound left open (abscess/trauma). Heals from bottom up via granulation and contraction. Slow, large scar.
Tertiary Intention: Delayed primary closure. Left open for 3-5 days (for infection/swelling to subside) then sutured.
factors:
Factors Affecting Healing

Systemic: Age, Malnutrition (Protein, Vit C, Zinc), Diabetes (microvascular ischemia/infection), Steroids (inhibit inflammation/collagen), Smoking (vasoconstriction/hypoxia), Jaundice, Uremia.
Local: Infection (Commonest cause of delay), Ischemia (tension/vascular disease), Foreign body, Hematoma, Radiation.

name: Sterilization & Disinfection
definitions:
Definitions

Cleaning: Physical removal of organic matter (blood/soil) using water/detergent. Essential first step.
Disinfection: Reduces viable organisms to a safe level. May not kill spores/viruses.
Sterilization: Complete destruction of ALL micro-organisms including Spores and Prions.
methods:
Sterilization Methods

  • Autoclave (Moist Heat): Steam under pressure. 121°C for 15 mins or 134°C for 3 mins. Gold standard for metal instruments. Kills spores.
  • Ethylene Oxide (Gas): For heat-sensitive items (plastics/tubing). Toxic/Flammable.
  • Gamma Irradiation: Industrial sterilization of single-use items (syringes, catheters).
agents:
Disinfectants/Antiseptics

Chlorhexidine: Binds to stratum corneum. Long acting/Residual effect. Alcohol-based is superior for skin prep.
Povidone Iodine: Broad spectrum. Inactivated by organic matter (blood).
Glutaraldehyde (Cidex): High-level disinfectant for flexible endoscopes (heat sensitive). Toxic fumes.

name: Sutures, Needles & Drains
sutures:
Suture Classification

  • Absorbable: Broken down by hydrolysis or enzymatic reaction.
    - Vicryl (Polyglactin): Braided. Holds tension 2-4 weeks. (Subcut, Bowel).
    - Monocryl (Poliglecaprone): Monofilament. (Subcuticular Skin).
    - PDS (Polydioxanone): Monofilament. Long lasting (6 weeks+). (Fascia/Mass closure).
    - Catgut: Enzymatic breakdown. Unpredictable (rarely used).
  • Non-Absorbable: Permanent.
    - Prolene (Polypropylene): Monofilament. Inert. (Vascular, Hernia Mesh).
    - Ethilon (Nylon): Monofilament. (Skin closure - remove).
    - Silk: Braided. (Drains, Ligatures).
needles:
Needle Types

Taper (Round body): Pierces tissue. Used for soft tissue (Bowel, Muscle, Fat).
Cutting: Triangular tip. Cuts through tough tissue. Used for Skin and Fascia.
drains:
Surgical Drains

  • Open Passive: Corrugated rubber. High infection risk (2-way track). Rarely used.
  • Closed Passive: Robinson drain. Gravity dependent.
  • Closed Active (Suction): Jackson-Pratt / Redivac. Negative pressure reduces dead space. Used in Mastectomy, Thyroidectomy, Ortho.
  • Indications: Remove fluid (blood/pus/bile), eliminate dead space, monitor for leak (sentinel drain).

name: Wound Classification
cdc_class:
CDC Wound Classification

  • Class I (Clean): Uninfected operative wound. No inflammation. Respiratory, GI, Genitourinary tracts NOT entered. Primary closure. Infection risk: <2%. (e.g., Hernia repair, Mastectomy, Thyroidectomy).
  • Class II (Clean-Contaminated): Respiratory, GI, or GU tracts entered under controlled conditions. No unusual contamination. Infection risk: <10%. (e.g., Elective Cholecystectomy, Elective Colectomy).
  • Class III (Contaminated): Open, fresh, accidental wounds. Major break in sterile technique. Gross spillage from GI tract. Acute non-purulent inflammation. Infection risk: 15-20%. (e.g., Stab wound, Bile spillage during chole).
  • Class IV (Dirty/Infected): Old traumatic wounds (>4h), devitalized tissue, existing clinical infection (pus) or perforated viscera. Infection risk: >40%. (e.g., Perforated diverticulitis, Abscess drainage).

name: Amoebic Liver Abscess
etiology:
Etiology

Caused by Entamoeba histolytica protozoa. Fecal-oral transmission (cysts). Trophozoites invade colon (flask-shaped ulcers) -> Portal vein -> Liver (Liquefactive necrosis). Common in tropical regions / alcoholics.
clinical_features:
Presentation

RUQ pain (may refer to right shoulder), High swinging fever, Rigors, Night sweats, Weight loss.
Signs: Tender hepatomegaly, Intercostal tenderness. Jaundice is rare.
Complication: Rupture into pleura (empyema), pericardium (tamponade), or peritoneum.
management:
Management

Investigation: USG (Hypoechoic, ill-defined), Serology (Amoebic Ab >95% sensitive). Aspiration yields 'Anchovy Sauce' pus (Sterile, odorless, necrotic hepatocytes).
Treatment: Metronidazole 800mg TDS for 10 days (Cures >90%). Follow with Diloxanide Furoate (luminal agent) to clear gut cysts. Aspiration only if: Large (>10cm), Left Lobe (Pericardial risk), or Failure of medical therapy.

name: Gastric Outlet Obstruction
etiology:
Causes

Benign: Chronic Peptic Ulcer Disease (Scarring/Fibrosis of pylorus), Adult Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis.
Malignant: Antral Gastric Cancer, Pancreatic Head Cancer invading duodenum, Lymphoma.
metabolic_derangement:
Hypochloremic Metabolic Alkalosis

Vomiting Gastric Acid (HCl) -> Loss of H+ and Cl- -> Alkalosis.
Paradoxical Aciduria: Dehydration leads to Aldosterone release to save Na+. Kidney initially exchanges Na+ for K+ (Hypokalemia). When K+ depleted, it exchanges Na+ for H+. Thus, acid (H+) is excreted in urine despite alkalotic blood.
clinical_features:
Presentation

Projectile vomiting of undigested food (non-bilious), Weight loss, Early satiety.
Signs: Dehydration, Visible Peristalsis (L to R), Succussion Splash (sloshing sound on shaking abdomen >4h post-meal).
management:
Management

1. Resuscitation: Wide bore NG Tube (Lavage/Decompression). IV Fluids (0.9% Saline + K+). Avoid Hartmann's (Lactate -> Bicarb -> Worsens alkalosis).
2. Diagnosis: OGDS (Biopsy).
3. Definitive: Balloon Dilation (Benign) or Stent/Gastrojejunostomy (Malignant).

name: Fistula-in-Ano
etiology:
Etiology

Cryptoglandular Theory (90%): Infection of intersphincteric anal glands -> Abscess -> Bursts into anal canal and skin -> Fistula tract.
Secondary Causes: Crohn's Disease (Multiple/Complex), TB, Malignancy, Radiation.
classification:
Parks Classification

1. Intersphincteric (45%): Most common. Tract confined between sphincters.
2. Trans-sphincteric (30%): Crosses external sphincter.
3. Suprasphincteric: Loops over Puborectalis.
4. Extrasphincteric: From rectum to skin (bypass sphincters).
clinical_features:
Goodsall's Rule

Predicts track path.
Anterior Opening: Radial straight track to dentate line.
Posterior Opening: Curved track to posterior midline (6 o'clock).
Exception: Anterior openings >3cm from anal verge track posteriorly.
management:
Treatment

Investigation: MRI Pelvis (Gold standard) or EUA.
Low Fistula (Not involving much sphincter): Fistulotomy (Lay open).
High Fistula: Sphincter-preserving. Seton (thread to drain/cut slowly), LIFT procedure, or Flap.

name: Diverticular Disease
pathology:
Pathophysiology

Acquired herniation of mucosa/submucosa through muscularis propria at weak points where vasa recta penetrate. Sigmoid Colon is most affected (Law of Laplace: High pressure, narrow lumen). Rectum is spared (complete muscle coat). Risk: Low fiber diet.
complications:
Complications

1. Diverticulitis: Inflammation/Micro-perforation. LIF pain, fever ('Left sided appendicitis').
2. Perforation: Fecal peritonitis (Hinchey IV). Surgical emergency.
3. Bleeding: Erosion of vasa recta. Major cause of massive painless lower GI bleed.
4. Fistula: Colovesical (Pneumaturia/UTIs) or Colovaginal.
management:
Management

Uncomplicated: Antibiotics, liquid diet.
Abscess (Hinchey II): CT-guided percutaneous drainage.
Perforation (Hinchey III/IV): Hartmann's Procedure (Resection of sigmoid + End Colostomy).
Bleeding: Resuscitation (most stop). Angio-embolization/Surgery if persistent.

name: Hemorrhoids
anatomy:
Anal Cushions

Normal vascular cushions (sinusoids) at 3, 7, and 11 o'clock.
Internal: Origin above dentate line. Visceral sensation (Painless). Covered by mucosa.
External: Origin below dentate line. Somatic sensation (Painful if thrombosed). Covered by skin.
clinical_features:
Presentation

Bleeding: Bright red, splash in the pan, separate from stool.
Prolapse Grading:
I: Bleed only, no prolapse.
II: Prolapse but spontaneous reduction.
III: Prolapse requiring manual reduction.
IV: Irreducible prolapse.
Pain: UNUSUAL for internal piles unless thrombosed/strangulated.
management:
Treatment

Conservative: Fiber, fluids, laxatives.
Office Procedures (Grade I/II): Rubber Band Ligation (Gold standard - causes necrosis/sloughing), Sclerotherapy.
Surgical (Grade III/IV): Hemorrhoidectomy (Milligan-Morgan) or Stapled Hemorrhoidopexy (PPH).

name: Skin Malignancies
bcc:
Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC)

Most common. Arises from basal layer. UV exposure.
Features: Pearly nodule, rolled edge, telangiectasia, central ulcer ('Rodent Ulcer').
Behavior: Locally invasive (can destroy bone/cartilage) but Metastasis is extremely rare.
Rx: Excision (3-4mm margin), Mohs surgery (face), Radiotherapy.
scc:
Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC)

Arises from keratinocytes. Precursor: Actinic Keratosis / Bowen's.
Features: Everted edge, keratin pearl, ulcerated.
Marjolin's Ulcer: SCC arising in chronic wound/burn scar/sinus. Aggressive.
Behavior: Metastasizes to regional lymph nodes.
Rx: Wide excision (1cm margin), Node clearance if palpable.
melanoma:
Malignant Melanoma

Arises from melanocytes.
ABCDE: Asymmetry, Border irregular, Color variation, Diameter >6mm, Evolution.
Prognosis: Depends on Breslow Thickness (depth).
Rx: Wide excision (margin depends on depth) + Sentinel Node Biopsy.

name: Flail Chest
pathophysiology:
Pathophysiology

Fracture of 3 or more consecutive ribs in 2 or more places. Creates a floating segment.
Paradoxical Respiration: Segment moves IN on inspiration, OUT on expiration.
Hypoxia Mechanism: NOT just mechanics. Primary cause is the underlying Pulmonary Contusion (bruised lung -> shunting/edema) and Pain (splinting -> atelectasis).
management:
Management Priorities

1. Analgesia: Epidural, Paravertebral Block, or PCA is critical to allow coughing/breathing.
2. Oxygen/CPAP: Positive pressure splints the chest internally.
3. Intubation: Indicated for respiratory failure (Hypoxia/Hypercapnia) despite analgesia.

name: Intussusception
etiology:
Etiology

Telescoping of proximal bowel (intussusceptum) into distal (intussuscipiens). Usually Ileum into Cecum.
Children (3m-3y): Idiopathic (90%). Peyer's patch hyperplasia (post-viral) acts as lead point.
Adults: Pathological lead point (Polyp, Tumor, Meckel's) is present in 90%.
clinical_features:
Clinical Features

Triad:
1. Intermittent colicky pain (infant screams/draws legs up, pallor).
2. 'Redcurrant jelly' stool (late sign - mucosal ischemia/blood/mucus).
3. Palpable sausage-shaped mass (RUQ) + Empty RIF (Sign of Dance).
management:
Management

Investigation: USG ('Target' or 'Doughnut' sign).
Treatment:
- Radiological: Air or Barium Enema reduction. Diagnostic and Therapeutic. Success >80%. Contraindicated if peritonitis/shock.
- Surgical: If enema fails, peritonitis, or pathological lead point. Manual reduction or resection.

name: Varicocele
anatomy:
Pathology

Dilatation of pampiniform venous plexus. 90% Left sided.
Why Left? Left Testicular vein drains vertically into Renal Vein (high pressure) at right angle. Right drains obliquely into IVC. Also compressed by SMA ('Nutcracker phenomenon').
management:
Clinical Features & Rx

Signs: 'Bag of worms' feel. Cough impulse. Disappears on lying down (if it doesn't -> Retroperitoneal mass).
Red Flag: Sudden onset Left varicocele or ANY Right varicocele suggests Renal Cell Carcinoma (tumor thrombus in renal vein).
Complication: Infertility (raised scrotal temp).
Rx: Embolization or Surgical Ligation.

name: Hydronephrosis
etiology:
Etiology

Dilation of renal pelvis/calyces due to obstruction.
Unilateral: Stone (Ureteric), Stricture, TCC Ureter, Pelvi-ureteric Junction Obstruction (PUJO), Extrinsic compression.
Bilateral: Bladder Outflow Obstruction (BPH, Ca Prostate), Urethral Stricture, Retroperitoneal Fibrosis.
management:
Management

Investigation: USG (Grade dilation), CT KUB (Stones), MAG3 Renogram (Differentiates functional obstruction from non-obstructive dilation).
Treatment: Relieve obstruction to save kidney.
- Upper: JJ Stent or PCN (Nephrostomy).
- Lower: Catheter (Urethral/Suprapubic).

name: Keloids vs Hypertrophic Scar
features:
Comparison

Keloid: Overgrowth of dense collagen (Type I & III). Extends BEYOND original wound boundaries. No regression. High recurrence. Genetic/Dark skin predisposition. Sites: Sternum, Earlobes, Deltoid.
Hypertrophic Scar: Confined WITHIN wound boundaries. Occurs at sites of tension/delayed healing. Often regresses spontaneously with time.
management:
Treatment

Keloid: Difficult. Intralesional Steroids (Triamcinolone). Pressure garments. Silicone gel. Excision ALONE has >50% recurrence (must combine with adjuvant steroid/radiotherapy).
Hypertrophic: Silicone gel, pressure, time.
